subject: Re: JUnit (and/or TestNG) on J2ME (was: Re: [junit] TestSuite - Order of test execution)
msgSnippet: Oops, sorry. I kept reading CLDC whenever you wrote CDC . Reflection is definitely an option then. I still think that there is little point in testing on
messageBody:
Oops, sorry. I kept reading "CLDC" whenever you wrote "CDC". Reflection is
definitely an option then.

I still think that there is little point in testing on the device itself. Or
rather, that it makes little sense as long as you don't have a set of tests
on the emulator.

--
Cedric


On 9/19/05, John H. E. <johnemb@...> wrote:
>
>
>
> --- Cedric Beust <cbeust@...> wrote:
>
> > On 9/19/05, John H. E. <johnemb@...> wrote:
> >
> > > No, TestNG is just a test harness, like JUnit.
> > >
> > > I'm guessing you could always use junit.jar on a J2ME CDC device...
> > But
> > > are there any reasons why using the Junit framework/harness on a J2ME
> > CDC
> > > platform/configuration would not work? Anyone?
> >
> >
> > First of all, there is no reflection on a CDC device, so that's not an
> > option. There is J2MEUnit, which addresses that, but I will argue that
> > testing on the device is not what is needed.
>
> I believe you are misunderstanding something here. J2ME CDC - 1.0a
> Specification (JSR36)
> (http://jcp.org/aboutJava/communityprocess/final/jsr036/) includes the
> java.lang.reflect package, so reflection should work. J2ME CLDC, however,
> does not, as far as I know...
>
> Do you know of any other issues with Junit on a CDC device?
>
> Nevertheless, your emulator testing strategy may be a good idea, I agree
> to that.
>
> --
> John
